Improving Neural Optimal Transport via Displacement Interpolation

Jaemoo Choi
Georgia Institute of Technology
jchoi843@gatech.edu
&Yongxin Chen
Georgia Institute of Technology
ychen3148@gatech.edu
&Jaewoong Choi
Korea Institute for Advanced Study
chwj1475@kias.re.kr
Abstract

Optimal Transport (OT) theory investigates the cost-minimizing transport map that moves a source distribution to a target distribution. Recently, several approaches have emerged for learning the optimal transport map for a given cost function using neural networks. We refer to these approaches as the OT Map. OT Map provides a powerful tool for diverse machine learning tasks, such as generative modeling and unpaired image-to-image translation. However, existing methods that utilize max-min optimization often experience training instability and sensitivity to hyperparameters. In this paper, we propose a novel method to improve stability and achieve a better approximation of the OT Map by exploiting displacement interpolation, dubbed Displacement Interpolation Optimal Transport Model (DIOTM). We derive the dual formulation of displacement interpolation at specific time tğ‘¡titalic_t and prove how these dual problems are related across time. This result allows us to utilize the entire trajectory of displacement interpolation in learning the OT Map. Our method improves the training stability and achieves superior results in estimating optimal transport maps. We demonstrate that DIOTM outperforms existing OT-based models on image-to-image translation tasks.

1 Introduction

Optimal Transport (OT) problem (Villani etÂ al., 2009; PeyrÃ© etÂ al., 2019) explores the problem of finding the cost-optimal transport map that transforms one probability distribution (source distribution) into another (target distribution). Recently, there has been a growing interest in directly learning the optimal transport map using neural networks. Throughout this paper, we call these approaches as the OT Map. OT Map has been widely applied across various machine learning tasks by appropriately defining the source and target distributions, such as generative modeling (Rout etÂ al., 2022; Choi etÂ al., 2023; 2024a), image-to-image translation (Korotin etÂ al., 2023; Gushchin etÂ al., 2024; Fan etÂ al., 2022), and domain adaptation (Flamary etÂ al., 2016). OT Map is particularly well-suited for unsupervised (unpaired) distribution transport problems, as it enables the transport of one distribution into another using only a predefined cost function, without requiring data pairs.

Despite their potential, existing OT Map methods often encounter significant challenges in training stability. In particular, the OT models utilizing max-min objectives exhibit unstable training dynamics and sensitivity to hyperparameters (Makkuva etÂ al., 2020; Fan etÂ al., 2022; Rout etÂ al., 2022; Flamary etÂ al., 2016). These challenges limit their applicability to high-dimensional data. To address these instability issues, various approaches have been explored, such as introducing additional regularization terms in the learning objective (Rout etÂ al., 2022; Roth etÂ al., 2017) and generalizing the standard OT problem to the unbalanced optimal transport problem (Choi etÂ al., 2023; 2024b).

In this paper, we propose a novel approach for learning the optimal transport map based on displacement interpolation. We refer to our model as the Displacement Interpolation Optimal Transport Model (DIOTM). We identify a fundamental connection between the the (static) optimal transport map and displacement interpolation. Motivated by this relationship, we derive a max-min formulation of displacement interpolation, involving the optimal transport map and the time-dependent Kantorovich potential. Our experimental results demonstrate that DIOTM achieves more stable convergence and superior accuracy in approximating OT maps compared to existing methods. In particular, DIOTM achieves competitive FID scores in image-to-image translation tasks, such as 5.27 for Maleâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Female (64Ã—64646464\times 6464 Ã— 64), 7.40 for Maleâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Female (128Ã—128128128128\times 128128 Ã— 128), and 10.72 for Wildâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Cat (64Ã—64646464\times 6464 Ã— 64), comparable to the state-of-the-art results. Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We propose a method for learning the optimal transport map based on displacement interpolation.

  • â€¢

    We derive the dual formulation of displacement interpolation and utilize this to formulate a max-min optimization problem for the transport map and potential function.

  • â€¢

    We introduce a novel regularizer, called the HJB regularizer, derived from the optimality condition of the potential function.

  • â€¢

    Our model significantly improves the training stability and accuracy of existing OT Map models that leverage min-max objectives.

2 Background

In this section, we provide a brief overview of key concepts in Optimal Transport theory. These results, especially the dual formulation and displacement interpolation, will play a crucial role in our proposed method.

Optimal Transport

The optimality of the transport plan is defined as the minimization of a given cost function. 3 Method

In this section, we propose our method, called the Displacement Interpolation Optimal Transport Model (DIOTM). Our model leverages displacement interpolation to improve the stable estimation of the optimal transport map using neural networks. In Sec 3.1, we derive our two main theorems for deriving our learning objective. In Sec 3.2, we describe how we implement our DIOTM model based on these theoretical results.

3.1 Dual Formulation of DI and the Relationship between Interpolation Potential Functions

In this subsection, we provide two theoretical results: the Dual Formulation of Displacement Interpolation (Thm 3.1) and the Relationship between Interpolation Potential Functions (Thm 3.3). Thm 3.1 will be utilized to derive our main learning objective (Eq. 18) and Thm 3.3 will be employed to formulate our regularizer (Eq. 20).

3.2 Displacement Interpolation Optimal Transport Model

In this subsection, we introduce our model, called Displacement Interpolation Optimal Transport Model (DIOTM). The goal of our model is to learn the optimal transport map between the source distribution Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼ and the target distribution Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½. DIOTM is trained by utilizing the displacement interpolation Ïtâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹†\rho_{t}^{\star}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (Eq. 7) between these two distributions. By leveraging the optimal intermediate dynamics connecting two distributions, our model achieves a stable estimation of the optimal transport map.

Algorithm

We present our training algorithm for DIOTM (Algorithm 1). Our adversarial training objective â„’Ï•,Î¸subscriptâ„’italic-Ï•ğœƒ\mathcal{L}_{\phi,\theta}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• , italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT updates alternatively between the value function VÏ•subscriptğ‘‰italic-Ï•V_{\phi}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the two transport maps Tâ†’Î¸,Tâ†Î¸subscriptâ†’ğ‘‡ğœƒsubscriptâ†ğ‘‡ğœƒ\overrightarrow{T}_{\theta},\overleftarrow{T}_{\theta}overâ†’ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , overâ† start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, similar to GAN framework (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2020). Note that we simplified Algorithm 1 by omitting the non-dependent terms for each neural network. Additionally, we apply the HJB regularizer to both generated distributions, i.e., the forward generated distribution from Tâ†’Î¸subscriptâ†’ğ‘‡ğœƒ\overrightarrow{T}_{\theta}overâ†’ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the backward generated distribution from Tâ†Î¸subscriptâ†ğ‘‡ğœƒ\overleftarrow{T}_{\theta}overâ† start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, throughout all experiments, we use the uniform distribution for time sampling, i.e., tâˆ¼Uâ¢[0,1]similar-toğ‘¡ğ‘ˆ01t\sim U[0,1]italic_t âˆ¼ italic_U [ 0 , 1 ]. However, the time sampling distribution can be freely modified. We leave the investigation of the optimal time sampling distribution to future work. In particular, if we set tâˆ¼Î´1similar-toğ‘¡subscriptğ›¿1t\sim\delta_{1}italic_t âˆ¼ italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., t=1ğ‘¡1t=1italic_t = 1, the training algorithm becomes similar to OTM (Rout etÂ al., 2022). In this case, we do not use any displacement interpolation information for tâˆˆ(0,1)ğ‘¡01t\in(0,1)italic_t âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ). The only difference is our HJB regularizer.

4 Related Work

OT problem addresses a transport map between two distributions that minimizes the predefined cost function. Starting from the dual formulations (Kantorovich, 1948; Vacher & Vialard, 2022a; b; GallouÃ«t etÂ al., 2021), diverse methods for estimating OT Map have been developed based on minimax problem (Liu etÂ al., 2019; Makkuva etÂ al., 2020; An etÂ al., 2020; Fan etÂ al., 2022; Rout etÂ al., 2022; Choi etÂ al., 2023; 2024b; Korotin etÂ al., 2023). In particular, Fan etÂ al. (2022); Rout etÂ al. (2022) and Korotin etÂ al. (2023) derived adversarial algorithm from the semi-dual formulation of OT problem and properly recovered OT maps compared to other previous works (Makkuva etÂ al., 2020). Moreover, they provided moderate performance in image generation and image translation tasks for large-scale datasets. Another line of research focuses on the dynamical formulation of OT problems (Chen etÂ al., 2021; Shi etÂ al., 2024b; Liu etÂ al., 2024; 2022; Neklyudov etÂ al., 2023; Gushchin etÂ al., 2024). Several works (Zhang & Chen, 2021; Chen etÂ al., 2021; Shi etÂ al., 2024b; Liu etÂ al., 2024) use sampling-based approaches, which require numerically simulating ODEs or SDEs during training. More recently, some methods (Neklyudov etÂ al., 2023; Gushchin etÂ al., 2024) have introduced simulation-free techniques, often incorporating adversarial learning strategies. Since our approach also leverages the dynamical properties of OT, we compare our method with Shi etÂ al. (2024b); Gushchin etÂ al. (2024), both of which have demonstrated scalability in image translation tasks.

5 Experiments

In this section, we conduct experiments on various datasets to evaluate our model from the following perspectives:

  • â€¢

    In Sec 5.1, we compare our model with the ground-truth solution from POT Flamary etÂ al. (2021) on synthetic datasets to assess how well our model approximates OT maps.

  • â€¢

    In Sec 5.2, we compare our model with various OT models on image-to-image translation tasks to evaluate the scalability of our model.

  • â€¢

    In Sec 5.3, we evaluate the training stability of our DIOTM model and investigate the effectiveness of HJB regularizer compared to other approaches, such as OTM regularizer and R1 regularizer.

For implementation details of experiments, please refer to Appendix B.

5.1 Optimal Transport Map Evaluation on Synthetic Datasets

First of all, we evaluate whether our model can accurately learn the optimal transport map Tâ‹†superscriptğ‘‡â‹†T^{\star}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the source distribution Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼ and the target distribution Î½ğœˆ\nuitalic_Î½. We assess our model against OTM (Rout etÂ al., 2022; Fan etÂ al., 2022) by comparing them to the discrete OT solution from the POT library (Flamary etÂ al., 2021). As discussed in Sec 3.2, when the time sampling distribution is set to Î´t=1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘¡1\delta_{t=1}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, our DIOTM presents a similar framework with OTM. Hence, we consider OTM an appropriate baseline for demonstrating the advantage of using displacement interpolation. Note that OTM demonstrated the most competitive performance as a neural optimal transport map in Korotin etÂ al. (2022b). Also, the discrete OT solution indicates the optimal transport map between empirical distributions, i.e., Î¼=âˆ‘iÎ´xi,Î½=âˆ‘jÎ´yjformulae-sequenceğœ‡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœˆsubscriptğ‘—subscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—\mu=\sum_{i}\delta_{x_{i}},\nu=\sum_{j}\delta_{y_{j}}italic_Î¼ = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î½ = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, computed via convex optimization. Hence, this discrete OT solution serves as the proxy ground-truth solution of the continuous OT map. We tested our model on four synthetic datasets: Gaussian-to-8Gaussian (Gâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’8G), Gaussian-to-25Gaussian (Gâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’25G), Moon-to-Spiral, and Gaussian-to-Circles (Gâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Circles).

5.2 Scalability Evaluation in Image-to-Image Translation Tasks

We assessed our model on several Image-to-Image (I2I) translation benchmarks: Male â†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’ Female (Liu etÂ al., 2015) (64Ã—64646464\times 6464 Ã— 64), Wild â†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’ Cat (Choi etÂ al., 2020) (64Ã—64646464\times 6464 Ã— 64), and Male â†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’ Female (Liu etÂ al., 2015) (128Ã—128128128128\times 128128 Ã— 128). Intuitively, the optimal transport map serves as a generator for the target distribution, which maps each input xğ‘¥xitalic_x to its cost-minimizing counterpart yğ‘¦yitalic_y. For instance, if we consider Male â†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’ Female task with the quadratic cost â€–xâˆ’yâ€–22superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¥ğ‘¦22\|x-y\|_{2}^{2}âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_y âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the optimal transport map translates each male image into a female image while minimizing the pixel-level difference. Consequently, various (entropic) optimal transport approaches are widely used for the I2I translation tasks. Therefore, we compared our model with the optimal transport models (NOT (Fan etÂ al., 2022) and OTM (Rout etÂ al., 2022)) and the entropic optimal transport models (DSBM (Shi etÂ al., 2024a) and ASBM (Gushchin etÂ al., 2024)) on image-to-image (I2I) translation tasks.

Fig. 2 and 3 present the I2I translation results. In each figure, the left subfigure shows source image samples. The right subfigure displays the translated images generated by our transport map. DIOTM successfully generates the target distributions (Cat and Female images) while preserving the identity of the input source images. In practice, our DIOTM model trains two transport maps in both directions Tâ†’Î¸subscriptâ†’ğ‘‡ğœƒ\overrightarrow{T}_{\theta}overâ†’ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tâ†Î¸subscriptâ†ğ‘‡ğœƒ\overleftarrow{T}_{\theta}overâ† start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The results for the reverse image-to-image translation are included in Appendix C. Tab. 2 provides the quantitative evaluation results. We adopted the FID score (Heusel etÂ al., 2017) for quantitative comparison. The FID score assesses whether each model accurately generates the target distribution. As shown in Tab. 2, the DIOTM model demonstrates state-of-the-art results among existing (entropic) OT-based methods on I2I translation benchmarks. Specifically, our model significantly outperforms other entropic OT-based models with a FID score of 7.40 in the higher resolution case of Male â†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’ Female (128Ã—128128128128\times 128128 Ã— 128). While OTM achieved comparable results at a specific hyperparameter of Î»=10ğœ†10\lambda=10italic_Î» = 10, OTM diverges for all other Î»âˆˆ{50,100}ğœ†50100\lambda\in\{50,100\}italic_Î» âˆˆ { 50 , 100 } with FID>60FID60\text{FID}>60FID > 60 (Fig. 5). In contrast, our DIOTM consistently maintains a stable performance of FID<10FID10\text{FID}<10FID < 10 for Î»âˆˆ{50,100}ğœ†50100\lambda\in\{50,100\}italic_Î» âˆˆ { 50 , 100 } (Fig. 5). In summary, DIOTM exhibits superior scalability in handling higher-resolution image datasets compared to previous OT Map models such as NOT and OTM.

5.3 Further Analysis

In this subsection, we provide an in-depth analysis of our DIOTM model. Specifically, we demonstrate the stable training dynamics of DIOTM, compare the HJB regularizer â„›â¢(VÏ•)â„›subscriptğ‘‰italic-Ï•\mathcal{R}(V_{\phi})caligraphic_R ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with various regularizers introduced in other neural optimal transport models, and conduct an ablation study on the regularization hyperparameter Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î».

Stable Training Dynamics

The previous approaches to neural optimal transport with adversarial learning often suffer from training instability (Choi etÂ al., 2024b). These models tend to diverge after long training and are sensitive to hyperparameters. In contrast, our DIOTM offers stable training dynamics. Fig. 5 visualizes the loss values for the transport map TÎ¸subscriptğ‘‡ğœƒT_{\theta}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the value function VÏ•subscriptğ‘‰italic-Ï•V_{\phi}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT throughout the training process. Note that we visualized these loss values on a log10subscript10\log_{10}roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT scale. In OTM (Rout etÂ al., 2022), the TÎ¸subscriptğ‘‡ğœƒT_{\theta}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT loss gradually explodes as training progresses. This unstable training dynamics has been a major challenge for the OT Map models based on minimax objectives. On the contrary, DIOTM exhibits stable loss dynamics without the abrupt divergence phenomenon, observed in OTM.

These regularizers are also introduced to stabilize the training value function VÏ•subscriptğ‘‰italic-Ï•V_{\phi}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In contrast, the FID scores of OTM fluctuate severely from below 20202020 to around 60606060 depending on Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î».

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we introduced the Displacement Interpolation Optimal Transport Model (DIOTM), a neural optimal transport method based on displacement interpolation. Our method is motivated by the equivalence between displacement interpolation and dynamic optimal transport. We derived the dual formulation of displacement interpolant and developed a method that utilizes the entire trajectory of displacement interpolation to improve neural optimal transport learning. Our experiments demonstrated that DIOTM achieves more accurate and stable optimal transport map estimation compared to previous method. A major limitation of this work is the requirement to train both bidirectional transport maps Tâ†’â†’ğ‘‡\overrightarrow{T}overâ†’ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG and Tâ†â†ğ‘‡\overleftarrow{T}overâ† start_ARG italic_T end_ARG. In image-to-image translation tasks, both transport maps are meaningful, e.g. Male â†”â†”\leftrightarrowâ†” Female. However, in generative modeling, the reverse transport map Tâ†â†ğ‘‡\overleftarrow{T}overâ† start_ARG italic_T end_ARG from the data to the prior noise distribution is not always necessary. In these cases, training Tâ†â†ğ‘‡\overleftarrow{T}overâ† start_ARG italic_T end_ARG can be an unnecessary cost.

Ethics Statement

In this paper, we aim to advance the field of machine learning by developing a relatively stable and high-performing algorithm. We hope that further investigation will enable our methodology to be applied as a stabilized algorithm across various machine learning applications. By providing a robust framework, we anticipate that our approach will contribute to improving the reliability and effectiveness of machine learning solutions in diverse contexts.

Reproducibility Statement

To ensure the reproducibility of our work, we submitted the anonymized source in the supplementary material, provided complete proofs of our theoretical results in Appendix A, and included the implementation and experiment details in Appendix B.

Network Architectures

We first describe the value function network VÏ•â¢(t,x)subscriptğ‘‰italic-Ï•ğ‘¡ğ‘¥V_{\phi}(t,x)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_x ). The input xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in\mathcal{X}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X is embedded using a two-layer MLP with a hidden dimension of 128. The time variable tğ‘¡titalic_t is embedded using a positional embedding of dimension 128, followed by a two-layer MLP, also with a hidden dimension of 128. These two embeddings are then added and passed through a three-layer MLP. The SiLU activation function is applied to all MLP layers. Besides, for the transport map networks, we employ the same network to Choi etÂ al. (2023) with hidden dimension of 128.

B.2 Image Translation

Training Hyperparameters

We follow the large neural network architecture introduced in Xiao etÂ al. (2021). We use Adam optimizer with (Î²1,Î²2)=(0,0.9)subscriptğ›½1subscriptğ›½200.9(\beta_{1},\beta_{2})=(0,0.9)( italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( 0 , 0.9 ), learning rate of 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and trained for 60K iterations. We use a cosine scheduler to gradually decrease the learning rate from 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 5Ã—10âˆ’55superscript1055\times 10^{-5}5 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The batch size of 64 and 32 is employed for 64x64 and 128x128 image datasets, respectively. We use Î±=0.001ğ›¼0.001\alpha=0.001italic_Î± = 0.001 for CelebA image dataset, and Î±=0.0005ğ›¼0.0005\alpha=0.0005italic_Î± = 0.0005 for AFHQ dataset. We use ema rate of 0.9999 for 64x64 image datasets and 0.999 for 128x128 image datasets.

Evaluation Metric

For the Wildâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Cat experiments, we compute FID based on train datasets of the target dataset and generate samples from each source samples. This follows the implementation of DeÂ Bortoli etÂ al. (2024). We sampled ten generated samples from each source. For CelebA experiments, we follow the metric used in Korotin etÂ al. (2023); Gushchin etÂ al. (2024). Specifically, we compute FID through test datasets.
